<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:4px; margin-bottom:0px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt" align=justify><B>Notes:</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-0.4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt" align=justify>The cut-off grade 
used for the Asanko Gold Mine &#150; Phase 1 Project resources (Nkran, Adubiaso,
Abore, Dynamite Hill &amp; Asuadai) was 0.8 g/t. Columns may not add up due to 
rounding. &nbsp;All figures are in metric tonnes. The Mineral Resources are 
stated as <I>in situ</I> tonnes. Individual densities were used per ore domain. 
The tonnages and contents are stated as 100%, which means no attributable 
portions have been stated in the table conversion from grams to ounces &#150; 
31.10348.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:6px; margin-bottom:0px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt" align=justify><B>Adubiaso and 
Nkran Extensions Development Timeline</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt" align=justify>Work is nearing completion on the Mineral Reserve 
Estimates for the two extensions, based on Whittle pit designs, waste dump 
planning and water management programs. The permitting process is also making 
good progress. As both deposits are located on the Company&#146;s existing 
Abriem mining lease, permitting only requires that a supplementary Environmental
Impact Study (&#147;EIS&#148;) be submitted to the relevant government 
regulatory bodies. &nbsp;The supplementary EIS for Adubiaso has been submitted 
and the requisite permits are expected to be granted by the end of Q3 2016. The 
Nkran extension permit applications are at an advanced stage of preparations and
will be lodged with the relevant regulatory bodies by the end of Q3 2016.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt" align=justify>Mining operation are expected to begin immediately 
following the receipt of the permits. &nbsp;As such, the two extensions have 
been incorporated into the new Asanko Gold Mine Life of Mine plan, which is 
expected to be announced in Q3 2016 as part of the Definitive Feasibility Study 
for the Phase 2 expansion project.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><B>Akwasiso Satellite Deposit</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Akwasiso deposit (Annexure 1) is located on the Nkran shear 
corridor and lies approximately 2 km north of the current Nkran pit, immediately
north of Nkran Extension and approximately 5km south of the Dynamite Hill 
deposit. &nbsp;Until recently the area was designated as Small Miner&#146;s 
Concessions. &nbsp;Asanko recently obtained the rights to the mineral 
concessions, which are contained within its existing Abirem mining lease.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-
size:9pt"><SUP>3</SUP> &nbsp;<FONT style="font-family:Arial; font-
size:8pt">Asanko Gold Mine Definitive Project Plan as filed on SEDAR on November
13, 2014.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>13</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt" 
align=justify>The Akwasiso target area is particularly prospective as it was 
previously drilled by the past owner of the Mineral Concessions and has a known 
non-compliant Mineral Resource Estimate. &nbsp;Asanko is completing a 5,000m 
diamond drilling program primarily designed to validate the geology and grade 
continuity of mineralized zones defined by the previous operator&#146;s campaign
in 2000 and 2001. The Company expects to publish an initial NI 43-101 compliant 
Mineral Resource Estimate during Q4 2016.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt" 
align=justify>To date a total of 3,500 metres of diamond drilling has been 
completed with assay results pending. &nbsp;Visual inspection of the current 
program&#146;s core shows similarities of the mineralization style to Nkran and 
other satellite deposits, with intrusive granite, a mixed sedimentary package, 
with altered and mineralized sandstone units with silicification and quartz 
veining. The historical drilling only evaluated the deposit to a depth of 100 
metres. The current program will incorporate deeper drilling to more fully 
understand the potential of the deposit. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Drilling results will
be announced as they become available.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:11pt"><B>5.4 Reserve and resource statements</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><B>Mineral Resources</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><B>Summary History</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">In February 2014, Asanko acquired PMI Gold Inc (&#147;PMI&#148;) 
and merged its Obotan project with the Esaase project to form what is now the 
Asanko Gold Mine. &nbsp;Following the acquisition, Asanko undertook a complete 
re-assessment of the mineral resource estimates (&#147;MRE&#148;) for the Obotan
project, namely the Nkran, Adubiaso, Abore, Dynamite Hill and Asuadai deposits 
which are now referred to as Phase 1 of the Asanko Gold Mine.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The re-assessment went back to first principles and included:</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-
indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; 
float:left">1.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The consolidation of all 
exploration and evaluation drilling data from prior operator Resolute Mining and
PMI, into one cohesive validated database.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-
indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; 
clear:left; float:left">2.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The use of independent 
geological experts to re-log diamond drill holes beneath the base of the old 
Resolute pit to understand structural controls to mineralization and mineral 
domains. This work produced a new geological model and provided a detailed 
framework to produce a detailed model for the deposits.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-
indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; 
clear:left; float:left">3.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The integration of the 
geological model into the estimate of classified Mineral Resources using 
industry&#146;s best practice techniques and undertaken by an independent
qualified person.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Mineral Resources were estimated in accordance with the 
guidelines of the Canadian Institute of Mines, Metallurgy and Petroleum 
(&#147;CIM&#148;) whose criteria are incorporated as the standard under Canadian
Securities regulators National Instrument 43-101 (&#147;NI 43-101&#148;) 
Disclosure Standards for Mineral Projects. The Independent Qualified Person 
(&#147;QP&#148;) was Charles Muller of CJM Consulting and the NI 43-101 
compliant technical report dated September 30, 2014, is filed on the 
Company&#146;s profile on SEDAR.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Mineral Resources for Phase 1 and Phase 2 of the Asanko Gold 
Mine, as of the date of this report, are summarized as follows:</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>14</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>

<DIV style="width:657.8px"><P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-
bottom:-2px; width:48px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; 
float:left"><I>Notes:</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><I>&nbsp;Due to rounding 
differences some M&amp;I totals may not add exactly with the Measured and 
Indicated figures. </I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><B><U>Qualified Person</U></B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Charles Muller is a QP under Canadian National Instrument 43-101 
(<I>Disclosure Standards for Mineral Projects</I>) and is independent of Asanko.
He conducted an extensive review of all of the available technical data, 
databases, systems and geological models. In addition, he has visited the Nkran 
deposit on multiple occasions. &nbsp;Mr. Muller has over 25 years of experience 
in resource modelling including specific, relevant experience acting as 
Independent QP since 1994 for Goldfields in Ghana. For the past 12 years he has 
been the QP for the Goldfields Damang Mine, also located in Ghana. Damang bears 
hydrothermal vein hosted mineralization similar to the Nkran deposit. Mr. Muller
is a member of both the Geostatistical Association of Southern Africa and the 
South African Council for Natural Scientific Professions (Pr. Sci. Nat. Reg. No.
400201/04).</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><B>Asanko Gold Mine Mineral Reserve Statement </B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">As a 
result of the positive economic outcomes of the May 2015 Asanko Gold Mine PFS a 
portion of the Company's Mineral Resources for Esaase were upgraded to Mineral 
Reserves. The<B>&nbsp;</B>Mineral Reserves were estimated in accordance with CIM
criteria for Mineral Reserves, incorporated as standard under NI 43-101. The 
Mineral Reserve Estimate was prepared by an independent engineering firm, DRA 
Projects SA (Pty) Ltd and can be found in a NI 43-101 compliant technical report
dated June 29, 2015 and filed on SEDAR.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Mineral Reserve Statement</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=right>15</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-0.933px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><B><U>Qualified 
Person</U></B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-0.933px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">Thomas Obiri-Yeboah, Pr. Eng., 
Senior Mining Engineer of DRA Projects SA, is a QP under NI 43-101 and is 
independent of Asanko. The Mineral Reserve Estimate was prepared under his 
supervision. He is a member of the Engineering Council of South African, 
Registration #20100340. His technical expertise includes over 20 years in the 
mining sector covering production, planning and project work and he has been 
involved in numerous projects around the world with both base and precious 
metals. He spent 12 years modelling gold deposits for AngloGold Ashanti in West 
Africa.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><B>Notes on Mineral 
Terminology</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">Mineral Resources and Reserves 
are derived from Canadian Institute of Mining definitions. Similar terminologies
are in use in Australia (JORC) and South Africa (SAMRAC) and are being 
considered in the United States.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">Mineral resources do not have 
demonstrated economic viability, but have reasonable prospects for eventual 
economic extraction. They fall into three categories: measured, indicated and 
inferred. Measured and indicated mineral resources can be estimated with 
sufficient confidence to allow the appropriate application of technical, 
economic, marketing, legal, environmental, social and governmental factors to 
support evaluation of the economic viability of the deposit. For measured 
resources: we can confirm both geological and grade continuity to support 
detailed mine planning. For indicated resources: we can reasonably assume 
geological and grade continuity to support mine planning.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">Mineral reserves are the 
economically mineable part of measured and/or indicated mineral resources 
demonstrated by at least a preliminary feasibility study. The reference point at
which mineral reserves are defined is the point where the ore is delivered to 
the processing plant. Mineral reserves fall into two categories: a) proven 
reserves: the economically mineable part of a measured resource for which at 
least a preliminary feasibility study demonstrates that economic extraction is 
justified; and b) probable reserves: the economically mineable part of a 
measured and/or indicated resource for which at least a preliminary feasibility 
study demonstrates that economic extraction is justified.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">United States investors are 
advised that while &#147;Measured&#148; and &#147;Indicated&#148; resources are 
recognized and required by Canada and other countries, the United States 
Securities and Exchange Commission does not recognize them. United States 
investors are cautioned not to assume that all or any part of Measured or 
Indicated Mineral Resources will ever be converted into Mineral Reserves. United
States investors are also cautioned not to assume that all or any part of an 
Inferred Mineral Resource exists, or is economically or legally mineable.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>16</P>

<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><I>Revenue and royalties</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Company declared commercial production at the AGM on April 1,
2016. &nbsp;In its first quarter of commercial operations, the Company sold 
35,074 ounces of gold at an average realized gold price of $1,231 for total 
revenue of $43.3 million (including $0.2 million of by-product revenue). 
&nbsp;The Company currently sells all of the gold it produces to Red Kite under 
an offtake agreement (see &#147;<B>8.</B> <B>Liquidity and capital 
resources&#148; </B>below). &nbsp;The Ghanaian government charge a 5% royalty on
revenues earned through sales of minerals, which is treated as a reduction of 
revenue in accordance with the Company&#146;s revenue recognition accounting 
policy. &nbsp;During the three months ended June 30, 2016, the Company 
recognized a reduction to revenue of $2.2 million relating to the royalty.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Company declared commercial production at the AGM on April 1,
2016 and as such the revenues and royalties reported for the six months ended 
June 30, 2016 are the same as those reported for the three-month period ended 
June 30, 2016. &nbsp;However, the Company did produce and sell gold in the first
quarter of 2016; the Company&#146;s pre-commercial production operations 
commenced January 1, 2016 with the mechanical completion of the processing 
facility, and ceased March 31, 2016 on the eve of the declaration of commercial 
production. In accordance with the Company&#146;s revenue recognition accounting
policy, during this period, the Company included as development costs the costs 
incurred for pre-commercial production mining, processing and support operations
offset by the revenue from saleable gold sold (net of royalties). &nbsp;&nbsp;A 
summary of the costs and revenues is provided below:</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0><TR 
height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=353.333 /><TD width=165.333 /></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-top:1px solid #000000; border-bottom:1px 
solid #000000" valign=bottom width=353.333><P style="margin:0px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt"><I>(in thousands of US 
dollars)</I></P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-top:1px solid #000000; border-bottom:1px 
solid #000000" valign=bottom width=165.333><P style="margin:0px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt" align=center><B>3 months ended 
March 31, 2016</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=353.333><P style="margin:0px;
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt">Costs incurred during pre-
commerical production</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=165.333><P 
style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt"
align=right>21,222</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom 
width=353.333><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-
size:8pt">Revenue during pre-commercial production, net of royalties</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom 
width=165.333><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-
size:8pt" align=right>(10,048)</P>
</TD></TR>

valign=bottom width=353.333><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New 
Roman; font-size:8pt"><B>Net costs deferred to development assets</B></P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1.333px solid #000000"

<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>

<P style="margin:0px" align=right>17</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><I>Production costs</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">During the three-month period ended June 30, 2016, the Company 
incurred production costs of $27.9 million relating to the sale of 35,074 ounces
of gold. &nbsp;In accordance with the Company&#146;s accounting policy for 
stripping costs, to the extent that excess waste is mined in an identified 
component of the mine during the period, as compared to the expected waste 
(based on the component-specific stripping ratio), a portion of costs are 
deferred to mineral properties. &nbsp;A total of $12.1 million of stripping 
costs were deferred to mineral properties during Q2 and are not included in cost
of sales. &nbsp;For a discussion of production costs incurred during the period 
see <B>&#147;4. Operating performance&#148; </B>above.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Company declared commercial production at the AGM on April 1,
2016 and as such the production costs reported for the six months ended June 30,
2016 are the same as those reported for the three-month period ended June 30, 
2016. &nbsp;Prior to April 1, 2016, all pre-commercial operating costs were 
capitalized (see &#147;<I>Revenue and royalties&#148; </I>above).</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><I>Depletion and depreciation</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Depletion of $8.97 million was recorded during the quarter as a
result of mining 1,238 tonnes of ore. &nbsp;Depletion of the mineral asset is 
charged to the statement of operations based on a units of production basis and 
is not impacted by any other factors. &nbsp;Depreciation of $4.0 million was 
recorded during the quarter in relation to plant, equipment and other fixed 
assets. &nbsp;All such assets are depreciated based on a units of production 
basis or straight-line over their useful economic lives. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The Company declared commercial production at the AGM on April 1,
2016 and at this point started depleting/depreciating production-related assets;
as such the depletion and depreciation costs which form part of production 
costs, as reported for the six months ended June 30, 2016 are the same as those 
reported for the three-month period ended June 30, 2016. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><I>General and administrative expenses</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">A summary of general and administrative expenses for the three 
and six months ended 2016 and 2015 is as follows:</P>

<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">General and administrative expenses remained reasonably 
consistent between Q2 2015 and Q2 2016. &nbsp;Higher wages and benefits in 2016 
as a result of higher headcount were offset by lower office, rent and 
administration costs and lower share-based payments. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">During the first six months of 2016, general and administrative 
expenses of $5.1 million were incurred in comparison to $3.9 million for the 
same period in 2015. &nbsp;The majority of the increase in cost was as a result 
of corporate reorganization costs incurred in 2016 in relation to the 
Company&#146;s Ghanaian subsidiaries which were reorganized to move all 
operating assets into the same legal entity and all exploration assets into a 
separate legal entity. &nbsp;Bonus payments for the achievement of production 
status at the AGM during the first quarter 2016 resulted in higher wages and 
benefits than the same period in 2015. &nbsp;The increases were offset by lower 
share-based </P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>18</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">payments in 2016 as the graded vesting schedule of the options 
resulted in a lower expense in 2016 as compared to 2015.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt"><I>Finance expense</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Total finance expense of $4.1 million incurred during Q2 consists
of $4.1 million of interest recognized in relation to the Company&#146;s $150 
million long-term loan (see <B>&#147;8. Liquidity and capital resources&#148; 
</B>below) and $0.1 million in accretion charges relating to the asset 
retirement obligation recognized in respect of the AGM. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Total finance expense of $4.3 million incurred during the six 
months ended June 30, 2016 consists of $4.1 million of interest recognized in 
relation to the Company&#146;s $150 million long-term loan (see <B>&#147;8. 
Liquidity and capital resources&#148; </B>below) and $0.2 million in accretion 
charges relating to the asset retirement obligation recognized in respect of the
AGM. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Finance expense for the three and six-month period ended June 30,
2016 is higher than for the same periods in 2015 as prior to the AGM being in
commercial production on April 1, 2016, all interest expenses relating to the 
long-term loan was capitalized to deferred development costs in accordance with 
the Company&#146;s accounting policy on borrowing costs. &nbsp;In 2015, finance 
expenses consisted primarily of accretion expense on the asset retirement 
obligation related to the AGM.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:36px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:11pt; float:left"><B>7)</B></P>

data</B></P>

font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The following table provides
summary unaudited financial data for the last eight quarters:</P>

<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">With the commencement of commercial production effective April 1,
2016, the Company began recording revenue and cost of sales in Q2 2016 (see 
<B>&#147;6. Financial results&#148;</B>). &nbsp;Exploration expenditures were 
higher in Q4, 2015 due to increased exploration work to identify new potential 
mining targets.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">General and administrative expense primarily consists of wages 
&amp; benefits, office rental costs, professional fees, legal fees, corporate 
reorganization, business development and share-based payments. &nbsp;These costs
were higher in Q4 2014 due to professional fees relating to the right-sizing of 
the Company&#146;s organizational structure post the acquisition of PMI, and 
higher in Q1 2016 as a result of a corporate reorganization and payment of 
bonuses upon reaching production status at the AGM (see <B>&#147;6. Financial 
results&#148;</B>). &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">Other income and expense in Q2 2016 includes interest expense on 
the Company&#146;s debt balance (see &#147;<B>8. Liquidity and capital 
resources&#148;</B>); prior to Q2 2016, interest incurred on the loan was 
capitalized to mine development costs. &nbsp;In addition, other income and 
expense primarily includes accretion on the asset retirement obligation 
associated with the AGM, movements in foreign exchange and </P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>19</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">fair value movements with respect to derivative financial 
instruments (see <B>`13. Risks and Uncertainties`)</B> which are marked-to-
market each reporting period. &nbsp;Further, in Q3 2014 a charge of $7.0 million
was recorded in other expenses with respect to the settlement of a legal 
dispute. &nbsp;Fluctuations in the other income (expense) lines in all other 
periods are due to movements in foreign exchange rates and changes in the fair 
value of derivative financial instruments.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">With the commencement of commercial production at the AGM on 
April 1, 2016, the related mineral properties, plant and equipment started being
depreciated for tax purposes; this resulted in a deferred income tax expense of 
$5.6 million in Q2 2016. &nbsp;The tax recovery in Q4 2015 related to the 
recognition of a deferred tax asset relating to the loan with Red Kite; the 
recovery in Q4 2014 related to a reduction in the deferred tax liability 
relating to mineral properties.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The loss per share incurred by the Company has remained 
reasonably consistent throughout the 8 periods.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:36px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:11pt; float:left"><B>8)</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:11pt"><B>Liquidity and capital 
resources</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">A key financial objective of the 
Company is to actively manage its cash balance and liquidity in order to meet 
the Company&#146;s strategic plan. &nbsp;The Company aims to achieve positive 
cash flows from operations to internally fund operating, capital and project 
development requirements. &nbsp;A summary of the Company&#146;s net assets and 
key financial ratios related to liquidity are as follows:</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">As evidenced by the Company&#146;s key financial ratios 
calculated above, the Company has a strong balance sheet, which the Company 
anticipates shall continue to strengthen now that the AGM is in commercial 
production. &nbsp;The Company was in a strong net asset position at both June 
30, 2016 and December 31, 2015 and had a significant cash balance of $34.5 
million as at June 30, 2016. &nbsp;Through a combination of this cash balance 
and cash flows from operations, the Company believes it is in a position to meet
all working capital requirements, contractual obligations and commitments as
they fall due (see &#147;<I>Commitments</I>&#148; below). &nbsp;However, the 
Company&#146;s cash flows and its ability to meet working capital requirements 
and contractual obligations is significantly influenced by the price of gold. 
&nbsp;The Company aims to manage its liquidity by ensuring that, even in a low 
gold price environment its operations can manage spending and provide adequate 
cash flow to meet all commitments.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>20</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><I>Debt</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">In 2013, the Company entered into a Definitive Senior Facilities 
Agreement (&#147;DSFA&#148;) with a special purpose vehicle of RK Mine Finance 
Trust I (&#147;Red Kite&#148;), which is now fully drawn for a total of $150 
million. &nbsp;Interest on the DFSA is calculated on a quarterly basis at a rate
of LIBOR +6% and there is a 1% minimum LIBOR rate which creates an interest rate
floor. The Company can elect to repay the DSFA, or a portion thereof, early 
without penalty. &nbsp;During the second quarter 2016, the DSFA was amended in 
order to defer the repayment of the principal for two years (being the principal
deferral period). The amendment provides that the first principal repayment will
now be payable on July 1, 2018 after which the facility will be repaid in nine 
equal quarterly installments, with the last repayment on July 1, 2020. The 
Company will continue to pay quarterly interest on the loan facility during the 
principal deferral period with the first interest payment on July 1, 2016. There
are no other changes to the existing debt facility terms. A deferral fee of 2% 
of the loan principal (for a total of $3.275 million) was paid commensurate with
signing the amendment. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">The amendment to the repayment of the loan was a key step by the 
Company to allow it more flexibility over a decision as to whether to progress 
with the construction of Phase 2. &nbsp;By delaying the repayment of the 
principal by two years, the Company has taken a significant step towards being 
able to fund the development of Phase 2 through cashflows from operations. 
&nbsp;No commitments with respect to capital expenditures have yet been made 
with respect to the development of the Esaase deposit (Phase 2); the Company 
hopes to make a construction decision prior to the end of 2016 following the 
publication of a definitive feasibility study with respect to Phase 2 (see 
&#147;<B>5. Development and exploration update</B>&#148;). &nbsp;There are no 
financial covenants under the DFSA, a copy of which is filed on SEDAR.com.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><I>Equity</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The Company is financially stable
with a total liabilities to equity ratio of 0.55. &nbsp;With the recent increase
in the Company&#146;s share price, the Company is seeing stock option exercises 
increase significantly, creating another source of financing for the Company 
(see &#147;<I>Cash flows</I>&#148; below).</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The Government of Ghana 
(&#147;the Government&#148;) has a 10% free carried interest in the AGM in 
accordance with Ghanaian Law; this was granted to through the issuance of 10% of
the common shares of the Company&#146;s Ghanaian subsidiary, Asanko Gold Ghana 
Limited (formerly &#147;Keegan Resources (Ghana) Limited&#148;), which owns the 
Abore, Abirem, Adubea and Esaase mining leases, to the Government. The 
Government has a nominee on the board of this subsidiary and is entitled to 10% 
of declared dividends being paid out of the subsidiary but does not have to 
contribute to its capital investment. </P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>

Roman; font-size:8pt" align=right><B>229,554</B></P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><I>Cash provided by operating 
activities</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">In the three months ending June 
30, 2016, the Company recorded cash flows from operations of $10.8 million, 
being cash inflows before working capital changes of $11.6 million and inflows 
from non-cash working capital of $6.5 million. &nbsp;The cash flows before 
working capital changes consist primarily of cash earnings from mine operations 
of $13.3 million less cash G&amp;A of $1.5 million. &nbsp;The inflow of $6.5 
million from non-cash working capital was the result of a $18.4 million increase
in accounts payable and accrued liabilities, a $5.5 million increase in
inventory and a $6.8 million increase in VAT receivable.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">In the six months ending June 30,
2016, the Company was only in commercial production for the last 3 months of the
period and as such cash flows from operations before working capital changes 
were the same as for the three months ended June 30, 2016 with the exception of 
additional G&amp;A costs of $3.2 million. &nbsp;Cash flows before working 
capital changes of $8.3 million consist primarily of cash earnings from mine 
operations of $13.3 million less cash G&amp;A of $4.6 million. &nbsp;The outflow
flow of $9.8 million from non-cash working capital was the result of a $22.9 
million increase in accounts payable and accrued liabilities, a $19 million 
increase in inventory and a $14.1 million increase in VAT receivable.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The prior period numbers do not 
form a good base for comparison as the Company was not yet in commercial 
production and cash flows from operating activities consisted mainly of general 
and administrative and exploration and evaluation expenditures.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><I>Cash used in investing 
activities</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">During Q2 2016, the Company spent
$54.5 million on mineral properties, plant and equipment. &nbsp;Of the total 
expenditure on investing activities during the period, $13 million related to 
the finalization of the development of the AGM, which included expenditures on 
ramp up and commissioning, electrical and instrumentation completion and piping 
and steelwork completion. &nbsp;In addition, $12.1 million of deferred stripping
costs were incurred during the three months ended June 30, 2016. &nbsp;Other 
cash expenditures during the period which were capitalized to mineral 
properties, plant and equipment related to the movement in working capital as 
amounts classified as accounts payable at the beginning of the period were paid 
during the period. &nbsp;During the same period in the prior year, the 
expenditures on investing activities were significantly higher as the Company 
was in the midst of developing the AGM in order to prepare for production to 
commence in early 2016. &nbsp;The expenditure in 2015 related predominantly to 
civil engineering infrastructure, earthworks and crushing, milling and 
processing complex construction.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">During the six-month period ended
June 30, 2016, the Company spend $82.3 million on mineral properties, plant and 
equipment. &nbsp;As discussed above, the majority of the expenditures in 2016 
have related to the finalization of the development of the AGM; a total of $45.4
million was spend on the development of the AGM in the first half of 2016. 
&nbsp;During the same period in the prior year, the expenditures on investing 
activities were significantly higher as the Company was in the midst of 
developing the AGM. &nbsp;The expenditure in 2015 related predominantly to 
civils, earthworks and crushing, milling and processing complex construction. 
&nbsp;Also included in the expenditures in the six-month period in 2016 are 
$12.1 million of deferred stripping costs and $11.1 million of pre-commercial 
production costs (see &#147;<B>6. Financial results&#148; </B>above). Other 
expenditures during the period which were capitalized to mineral properties, 
plant and equipment related to the movement in working capital as amounts 
classified as accounts payable at the beginning of the period were paid during 
the period</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>22</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">In the three and six months ended
June 30, 2016, the Company received total VAT refunds of $5.7 million and $5.7 
million respectively.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><I>Cash provided by (used in) 
financing activities</I></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">During
the three and six months ended June 30, 2016, the Company received a total of 
$3.4 million and $3.5 million respectively as a result of the exercise of stock 
options in the three and six-month period. &nbsp;In addition, during the three 
months ended June 30, 2016, the Company paid a deferral fee of $3.275 million in
relation to the amendment to the DSFA (see <I>&#147;Debt&#148; </I>above) as 
well as $2.9 million of interest relating to the same facility.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">During
the three and six months ended June 30, 2015, the Company drew down $70 million 
on its DSFA with Red Kite (see <I>&#147;Debt&#148;</I> above). &nbsp;The Company
recorded net proceeds of $67.2 million after draw down fees and deferred 
financing costs. &nbsp;In addition, in the six months ended June 30, 2015, the 
Company recorded $34.3 million (net of share issuance costs) with respect to a 
bought deal financing in which the Company issued 22.8 million shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:36px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:11pt; float:left"><B>9)</B></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:11pt"><B>Non-GAAP measures</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The Company has included certain 
non-GAAP performance measures throughout this document. These performance 
measures are employed by management to assess the Company&#146;s operating and 
financial performance and to assist in business decision-making. The Company 
believes that, in addition to conventional measures prepared in accordance with 
GAAP, certain investors and other stakeholders use this information to evaluate 
the Company&#146;s operating and financial performance; however, these non-GAAP 
performance measures do not have any standardized meaning. Accordingly, these 
performance measures are intended to provide additional information and should 
not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance 
prepared in accordance with GAAP. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-
size:9pt"><B>9.1) Cash Operating Costs Per ounce and Total Cash Costs per 
ounce</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The Company has included the non-
GAAP performance measures of cash operating costs per ounce and total cash costs
per ounce on a by-product basis, throughout this document. In the gold mining 
industry, this is a common performance measure but does not have any 
standardized meaning. The Company follows the recommendations of the Gold 
Institute Production Cost Standard. The Gold Institute, which ceased operations 
in 2002, was a non-regulatory body and represented a global group of suppliers 
of gold and gold products. The production cost standard developed by the Gold 
Institute remains the generally accepted standard of reporting cash costs of 
production by many gold mining companies. Management uses operating cash costs 
per ounce and total cash costs per ounce to monitor the operating performance of
its mines and to assess the attractiveness of potential acquisition targets. The
Company believes that, in addition to conventional measures prepared in 
accordance with GAAP, some investors use this information to evaluate the 
Company&#146;s performance and ability to generate cash flow. Accordingly, it is
intended to provide additional information and should not be considered in 
isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance 
with GAAP. The following table provides a reconciliation of total cash costs per
gold ounce on a by-product basis to operating expenses (the nearest GAAP 
measure) as presented in the consolidated financial statements of the Company; 
note that the Company has only provided Cash operating costs per gold ounce and 
Total cash costs per gold ounce for the three months ended June 30, 2016 as the 
Company only commenced commercial production on April 1, 2016.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><B>9.2
All-in Sustaining Costs Per Gold Ounce </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">In June 2013, the World Gold 
Council (&#147;WGC&#148;), a non-regulatory association of many of the 
world&#146;s leading gold mining companies established to promote the use of 
gold to industry, provided guidance for the calculation of &#147;all-in 
sustaining costs per gold ounce&#148; in an effort to encourage improved 
understanding and comparability of the total costs associated with mining an 
ounce of gold. The Company has adopted the reporting of &#147;all-in sustaining 
costs per gold ounce&#148;, which is a non-GAAP performance measure. &nbsp;The 
Company believes that the all-in sustaining costs per gold ounce measure 
provides additional insight into the costs of producing gold by capturing all of
the expenditures required for the discovery, development and sustaining of gold 
production and allows the Company to assess its ability to support capital 
expenditures to sustain future production from the generation of operating cash 
flows. The Company believes that, in addition to conventional measures prepared 
in accordance with IFRS, some investors use this information to evaluate our 
performance and ability to generate cash flow. Accordingly, it is intended to 
provide additional information and should not be considered in isolation or as a
substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance with IFRS. </P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The following table provides a 
reconciliation of all-in sustaining costs per gold ounce to the consolidated 
financial statements for the three and six months ended June 30, 2016 and 2015; 
note that the Company has only provided All-in sustaining costs per gold ounce 
for the three months ended June 30, 2016 as the Company only commenced 
commercial production on April 1, 2016.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0><TR 
height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=385 /><TD width=120 /></TR>

padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom 
width=120><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-
size:8pt" align=center><B>Three months ended June 30, 2016</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom 
width=385><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-
size:8pt">(in thousands of US dollars except per ounce amounts)</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom 
width=120><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-

</TD></TR>

</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=120><P style="margin:0px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt" align=right>12,135</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=385><P style="margin:0px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt">Reclamation cost 
accretion</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=120><P style="margin:0px;

</TD></TR>

</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-top:1px solid #000000; border-

</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=120><P style="margin:0px;

<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=385><P style="margin:0px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt"><B>All-in sustaining cost 
per gold ounce ($/ounce)</B></P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=120><P style="margin:0px; 
font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt" align=right>1,280</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">All-in sustaining costs adjust 
&#147;Total cash costs&#148;, for corporate general and administrative expenses,
reclamation cost accretion, sustaining capitalized stripping costs and 
sustaining capital expenditures. Corporate general and administrative expenses 
are included as a line item on the Company&#146;s statement of operations. 
Sustaining capital expenditures, capitalized stripping costs and reclamation 
cost accretion are not line items on the Company&#146;s financial statements. 
Sustaining capital expenditures are defined as those capital expenditures which 
do not increase annual gold ounce production at a mine site and exclude all 
expenditures at the Company&#146;s projects and certain expenditures at the 
Company&#146;s operating sites which are deemed expansionary in nature. 
Capitalized stripping </P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right>24</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin-top:12px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-
right:24px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:14pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><B>ASANKO GOLD INC.</B><FONT style="font-size:9pt">
</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">costs represent costs incurred
during the period which have been deferred to mining interests as they allow the
Company to gain access to ore to be mined in future periods; these costs relate 
to the currently identified reserves and resources and are not considered 
expansionary in nature. &nbsp;Reclamation cost accretion represents the growth 
in the Company&#146;s decommissioning liability due to the passage of time. This
amount does not reflect cash outflows but it is considered to be representative 
of the periodic costs of reclamation and remediation. Reclamation cost accretion
is included in finance expense in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of 
operations and comprehensive income (loss). </P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The following table reconciles 
sustaining capital expenditures to the Company&#146;s total capital expenditures
as presented in the Company&#146;s consolidated statement of cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><B>9.3
Adjusted Net Income (Loss) </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-right:-1.133px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The Company has included the non-
GAAP performance measures of adjusted net income (loss) and adjusted net income 
(loss) per share, throughout this MD&amp;A. &nbsp;Neither adjusted net income 
nor adjusted net income per share have any standardized meaning and are 
therefore unlikely to be comparable to other measures presented by other
issuers. &nbsp;Adjusted net income excludes certain non-cash items from net 
income or net loss to provide a measure which helps the Company and investors to
evaluate the results of the underlying core operations of the Company and its 
ability to generate cash flows. The Company believes that the presentation of 
adjusted net income is appropriate to provide additional information to 
investors regarding items that we do not expect to continue at the same level in
the future or that management does not believe to be a reflection of the 
Company&#146;s ongoing operating performance. The Company further believes that 
its presentation of this non-IFRS financial measure provides information that is
useful to investors because it is an important indicator of the strength of our 
operations and the performance of our core business. Accordingly, it is intended
to provide additional information and should not be considered in isolation or 
as a substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. 
The following table provides a reconciliation of adjusted net income to net 
income (the nearest GAAP measure) per the consolidated financial statements; 
note that the Company has only provided adjusted net income and adjusted net 
income per share for the three months ended June 30, 2016 as the Company only 
commenced commercial production on April 1, 2016 and as such management does not
consider this a useful measure prior to this date. &nbsp;All adjustments are 
shown net of tax.</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="line-height:14pt; margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; 
font-size:9pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-bottom:4px; font-
family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt; border-bottom:2px solid 
#000000">FOR THE THREE AND SIX MONTHS ENDED JUNE 30, 2016</P>
<P style="line-height:12pt; margin:0px; padding-top:4px; border-top:2px solid 
#000000"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt"><B>9.4
Operating cash flows before working capital changes </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Calibri,Times New Roman; font-size:9pt">The 
Company has included the non-GAAP performance measure operating cash flows 
before working capital changes in this MD&amp;A. Non-GAAP performance measures 
do not have any standardized meaning and are therefore unlikely to be comparable
to other measures presented by other issuers. The Company believes that, in 
addition to conventional measures, prepared in accordance with GAAP, certain 
investors use this information to evaluate the Company&#146;s performance and 
ability to generate cash flow. Accordingly, it is intended to provide additional
information and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for 
measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. The following table 
provides a reconciliation of operating cash flows before working capital changes
to cash (used in) provided by operating activities (the nearest GAAP measure) 
per the consolidated financial statements. &nbsp;Note that the Company has only 
provided operating cash flows before working capital changes for the three 
months ended June 30, 2016 as the Company only commenced commercial production 
on April 1, 2016 and as such management does not consider this a meaningful 
measure prior to this date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
